pullRequest.body:
Add lemmas that allow `IsLeft`/`IsRight` conclusions from `LiftRel` and allow for apply functions.

This is necessary because `cases` cannot run on statements like `LiftRel r s (f t) y`.

---

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

bors merge

```suggestion
    (âˆƒ b, x = inr b âˆ§ âˆƒ d, y = inr d âˆ§ s b d) := by
```

```suggestion
  refine' âŸ¨(fun H â†¦ _), (fun H â†¦ _)âŸ©
  Â· rcases H with (hac | hbd)
    Â· exact Or.inl âŸ¨_, rfl, _, rfl, hacâŸ©
    Â· exact Or.inr âŸ¨_, rfl, _, rfl, hbdâŸ©
  Â· rcases H with (âŸ¨_, rfl, _, rfl, hacâŸ© | âŸ¨_, rfl, _, rfl, hbdâŸ©)
    Â· exact liftRel_inl_inl.mpr hac
    Â· exact liftRel_inr_inr.mpr hbd
```
Putting e and f in the variable line seems a bit unnecessary if they are used only once. Its probably clearer to someone reading the file not to do this
Indentation here and below is also quite inconsistent, I'd go with no indent for a term mode proof
why this change?
Oh, it will have been an auto-replace. I was told we don't use lemma?
Really I should make this change in my other PR.

If you have a link to that I'd like to read the discussion.
My understanding was simply that mathport didn't use lemma so there are mostly "theorem"s in mathlib, but `mathlib` does add the lemma macro so it seems its up to personal preference to use it or not.
I just worry that by changing it we get into a weird state where some people are adding lemmas and other people changing them to theorems and its a lot of inessential changes. So it would be good to have either lemma banned across mathlib and fixed all at once or leave things as they are

Unfortunately it was on Kevin's discord. Though I also had such a comment in another PR recently...

I don't think there's any clear guidance currently. I don't understand what the criteria are.
Yeah in that case I think its better to just leave existing lines as they are then, until there becomes a clear consensus
It seems we're moving to a situation where most declarations are `lemma` and important ones are `theorem`.
I'm not going to change my PR for this though. I already changed it back.

This is very close to the lemma `LiftRel_iff` autogenerated by doing
`import Mathlib.Tactic.MkIffOfInductiveProp` and adding `@[mk_iff]` to `inductive LiftRel`. Have you considered using that either instead of this or to prove this more easily
Oh I didn't know about that. That's a nice feature and really the kinda thing I was looking for. (I don't use this in the rest of the file really but I figured we should have it.)
Indeed, its a feature I think is relatively not well known! So  I think there are many more places in the library it could be useful also but isnt yet
I think a lot of the time you don't need it (as you see from the rest of the proofs) but yeah wow that should really be a gimmee. I find in Mathlib4 finding good tactic documentation is much harder.

```suggestion
  (âˆ€ x, LiftRel r s x (e x)) â†” âˆ€ y, LiftRel r s (e.symm y) y := by
```
Hmm, I'm not sure how much I like specialising `Equiv.forall_congr_left'` to every possible forall.
That's very fair. It's just the kind of thing that tends to come up multiple times in a proof.
In the name of expediting the rest of this PR, I have removed this change.

```suggestion
  âˆƒ b d, s b d âˆ§ x = inr b âˆ§ y = inr d :=
```

Here and below:
```suggestion
  (isLeft_eq_of_liftRel h).symm
```
Huh. I was sure I had recieved advice that said when I was giving a direct term (rather than a tactic proof) I shouldn't indent.

Here and below:

```suggestion
    âˆƒ a c, r a c âˆ§ x = inl a âˆ§ y = inl c := by
```

```suggestion
theorem LiftRel.isLeft_congr (h : LiftRel r s x y) : x.isLeft = y.isLeft := by
```
but also ugh that would be nicer as
```suggestion
theorem LiftRel.isLeft_congr (h : LiftRel r s x y) : x.IsLeft â†” y.IsLeft := by
```
Happy to change that - in the time since I made this and now, Lean no longer seems to expand bools to "Bool = true" in the same way.

Hmm, it does actually. Well, if you think it's nicer I will change it. The thing is that sometimes you want to transform the expression itself... it's essentially down to which side of `Bool.eq_iff_iff` you prefer. (For what it's worth, changing to iff breaks some of my proofs in the same file.)
Nono, I meant that I would like  a Prop-valued `IsLeft` instead of the Bool-valued `isLeft`, but that's out of scope for this PR. Just pick the first suggestion :)
The iff is better anyway, changed.

```suggestion
theorem LiftRell.isLeft_right (h : LiftRel r s (inl a) y) : y.isLeft :=
```

```suggestion
theorem LiftRel.isLeft_left (h : LiftRel r s x (inl c)) : x.isLeft :=
```
etc
Sorry, why do we need these? Are they not literally syntactical specialisations of the previous?

You'd think that, I certainly did, but my recollection for when I was working on this back in September is that for some reason the typechecker couldn't prove things of this form using those lemmas. I can see if that has changed though.

I would be highly surprised if that were the case! I can understand the difference between having your first set of lemmas and not having any lemma, but I can't imagine that your second set of lemmas gives you anything more than your first set.
You are right! Removed.

```suggestion
theorem LiftRel.exists_of_isLeft_right (hâ‚ : LiftRel r s x y) (hâ‚‚ : y.isLeft) :
```

```suggestion
theorem LiftRel.exists_of_isRight_left (hâ‚ : LiftRel r s x y) (hâ‚‚ : x.isRight) :
```
Do you actually need these in practice? because you can just eliminate the existential and then this is just `LiftRel.inl` and `LiftRel.inr` again.
No I think you're probably right, I just felt it might be useful to unwrap them. But I'm not wedded to them so I'm happy to remove if you think that's better.

There might be an argument for having them but they're less clearly useful than the other lemmas in this PR so I think one of two things should happen now:
* either you go back to your project, try deleting the uses of these two lemmas and
  * either it's an awful mess and we keep them in this PR
  * or it's actually fine and we remove them from this PR
* or we remove the lemmas from this PR, merge it, you bump your project to the new mathlib and
  * either you can't remove the uses of the lemmas that didn't make it to mathlib and you open a new PR for them
  * or it's actually fine to only use what made it to mathlib and there's no need to do anything more

Oh in the end I didn't use these in my project because I wanted to do something in less generality in my specific case. But I still want to introduce it into mathlib in the appropriate generality. I'll remove these for now.

My strategy for integrating my project into mathlib is to do it in stages - I've factored out the stuff that is useful for reasons other than my specific definitions mostly, I'm just slowly PRing them all.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion theorem isLeft_left (h : LiftRel r s x (inl c)) : x.isLeft := by cases h; rfl ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion theorem isLeft_right (h : LiftRel r s (inl a) y) : y.isLeft := by cases h; rfl ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion theorem isRight_left (h : LiftRel r s x (inr d)) : x.isRight := by cases h; rfl ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion theorem isRight_right (h : LiftRel r s (inr b) y) : y.isRight := by cases h; rfl ```

Mathport completely broke this by adding `#align`s everywhere but in Lean 3 I used to group similar one-line lemmas visually. I still think it's worth doing.
```suggestion
theorem isLeft_congr (h : LiftRel r s x y) : x.isLeft â†” y.isLeft := by cases h <;> rfl
theorem isRight_congr (h : LiftRel r s x y) : x.isRight â†” y.isRight := by cases h <;> rfl

theorem isLeft_left (h : LiftRel r s x (inl c)) : x.isLeft := by cases h; rfl
theorem isLeft_right (h : LiftRel r s (inl a) y) : y.isLeft := by cases h; rfl
theorem isRight_left (h : LiftRel r s x (inr d)) : x.isRight := by cases h; rfl
theorem isRight_right (h : LiftRel r s (inr b) y) : y.isRight := by cases h; rfl
```
